awd_titl_txt: Cytokinesis without an actomyosin ring: studies in Chlamydomonas
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is about the evolution of cell division and will have broader significance in several ways.  First, it will help to counter the excessive focus of research in cell and molecular biology on the animals, fungi, and land plants.  There is an enormous amount to be learned about the huge diversity of other interesting cell types, many of which are also ecologically and/or economically important.  Second, it will provide Chlamydomonas researchers not only with new biological insights but also with valuable research tools, such as improved methods for regulated transgene expression and synchronization of cell division.  These tools should be of value not only for basic research but also for biotechnology, particularly in the biofuels industry, which in turn could have benefits for fuel supplies and environmental conservation.  Third, it will support the research career of a very talented young scientist and help him to progress into an independent academic position.  Finally, it will help to support the involvement of undergraduates, high-school students, and public-school teachers in research, with special emphasis on the teachers because of the large numbers of students that they themselves then go on to teach.  Nearly all previously hosted students (including many from underrepresented groups) have gone on in STEM fields, and the teachers have all carried ideas and materials from the laboratory back to their classrooms.  These patterns should continue under the current project.

This project will exploit the evolutionary position and experimental advantages of the green alga Chlamydomonas to elucidate the still-obscure core mechanisms of cytokinesis, the final step in cell division.  The focus is on how cells can form division furrows in the absence of a "contractile actomyosin ring" (CAR).  The CAR is found in animals and fungi and is composed of actin filaments, type II myosin, and other proteins.  It has long been thought to provide the force for furrow ingression via an actin-myosin interaction like that in muscle.  However, many cells that normally have a CAR can divide without it, as can the vast number of cell types (such as Chlamydomonas) that form furrows but have no type II myosin; thus, there must be another driver(s) of furrowing.  To elucidate these mechanisms, several related aims will be pursued.  First, a combination of microscopic, biochemical, pharmacological, and genetic methods will be used to analyze the possible roles of the actin and microtubule cytoskeletons.  Second, a similar combination of methods will be used to explore the possibility that the primary driver of furrow formation is localized growth of the plasma membrane and extracellular matrix.  Third, unbiased and targeted genetic screens will seek mutants with specific defects in cytokinesis; characterization of these mutants should help to reveal the underlying mechanisms that drive furrow formation.  These studies should help to elucidate both the shared mechanisms underlying the seemingly diverse modes of cytokinesis in modern organisms and the evolution of these modern mechanisms from those of ancestral cells.  Several lines of evidence suggest that the ancestral and still-core mechanism of cytokinesis is the localized deposition of new cell membrane and extracellular matrix, and that the actin and microtubule cytoskeletons play auxiliary roles in this process.  Chlamydomonas is an attractive system in which to investigate these issues.  It is evolutionarily distant from the organisms on which cytokinesis studies have previously focused; divides by furrow formation but does not have a type II myosin; has one conventional actin, one unconventional actin, and a well developed microtubule cytoskeleton; displays an enrichment of both actin and microtubules around the cleavage furrow; and has many genetic tools already available.  Its mechanisms of cytokinesis have hardly been studied, and elucidating them should contribute to a needed paradigm shift in the cytokinesis field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The funding period for this award overlapped extensively with the worst period of the COVID-19 pandemic, which of course led to lab closures, other disruptions, and many delays.  Nonetheless, by the end of the award period, we could report excellent progress both toward our scientific goals and with our educational activities.

Intellectual merit: 

Our principal research success was in regard to clarifying the mechanisms by which eukaryotic (higher) cells divide into two daughter cells.  For more than 50 years, it has been very widely believed that the division furrow is produced by a ring of filaments made of the proteins actin and myosin, which act on each other, as in muscle, to produce the force that pulls the cell membrane in to make the furrow.  However, we were able use a combination of genetic manipulations and inhibitors to show that cells of the green alga Chlamydomonas form functional cleavage furrows and divide successfully even in the complete absence of actin.  This result also suggests very strongly that the original eukaryotic cells – the ancestors of all modern types – also divided using furrow formation that did not depend on an actin/myosin ring, and that this latter structure was a more recent evolutionary invention that made cell division more efficient but is not its core mechanism.  Our continuing studies have so far revealed significant clues as to what the actual core mechanism is, but full elucidation of that mechanism remains a work in progress.

As often happens, several new methods that we developed or improved in pursuit of our primary research goals have proved useful in many other projects as well, leading to multiple other discoveries and resulting publications in collaboration with other research groups.

Broader impacts:

This project has been pivotal for the professional and career development of an exceptionally young scientist, Masayuki Onishi, who began as a Postdoctoral Research Associate in the Principal Investigator’s laboratory and now has an independent research group as an Assistant Professor in the Biology Department at Duke University.  At Duke, he is continuing his work on cell division in Chlamydomonas, teaching undergraduate and graduate students, training postdoctoral fellows, and engaging in a multitude of outreach activities in the Durham, North Carolina, area.  With the help of a subaward from this project, Dr. Onishi has gotten off to an excellent start despite the severe handicap of beginning his independent career during the height of the pandemic.

This project has also provided crucial training for a promising postdoctoral fellow, Dr. Manuella (Rossie) Clark-Cotton, who has worked both with the Principal Investigator and with Dr. Onishi on continuing investigations of the mechanisms of cell and organelle division in Chlamydomonas.  She is also taking a leading role in the preparation of a detailed review article that will attempt to bring the cell-division field up to date.  Dr. Clark-Cotton is a nontraditional student from a group underrepresented in science, and, perhaps for this reason, she has also been very active in outreach activities directed at other such students since she began working on this project. 

In addition, prior to the pandemic, we were able to continue a long-running program of providing research experience to high-school science teachers.  We hosted three such teachers during the summers of 2018 and 2018, and all three reported taking their experiences back to their classrooms during the following years.  Subsequently, when things opened up again, we were able to provide research experience to several high-school students from underrepresented groups.
